data.title: Jason Bateman Breaks Down His Career, From "Arrested Development" to "Ozark"
data.meta_description: Jason Bateman discusses his career, including Little House on the Prairie, Knight Rider, The Hogan Family, Teen Wolf Too, Moving Target, Simon, Chicago Sons, Some of My Best Friends, Arrested Development, Juno, and Ozark. Ozark Season 2 will be available only on Netflix August 31st.
data.text:
Hello, I'm Jason Bateman.

This is my career timeline.

(upbeat music)

♪ Oh those Golden Grahams ♪

♪ Taste like honey grahams ♪

It's a delicious honey graham taste.

So things started out in commercials

as a lot of careers do.

I loved doing it because I got to skip school.

And often times I got to sort of fun stuff,

go kart riding or bike riding and then eat a lot

of sugary cereal and get all hopped up.

That was fun for me as a kid.

I remember I had to kind of go down a hill

in kind of a soap box derby for one of these commercials

or show that I could follow a tape X on a stick

I remember for this Honey Nut Cheerios commercial.

My skillset was pretty high pretty early

and you could tell.

♪ Try those Golden Grahams and have a golden day ♪

(footsteps on stairs)

Little House on the Prairie

was sort of my first big type of thing.

I was on that show for a year, got adopted into that family.

I just remember them being a really nice group of people.

And Michael Landon was directing

and acting and writing the shows

and that was a great first experience

to have as a little kid.

Seeing that it's not a scary place the set.

I want you to come live with us.

Gee, Mr. Ingalls, gee.

Miss Summers?

Chicago may be the windy city,

but when you arrive it will be breathless.

(audience laughing)

After Little House on the Prairie went on to Silver Spoons

and a few other sitcoms for years after that.

Again, skipping school was a big part of the draw.

I wasn't too focused on money at the time,

didn't have to spend on a lot of things.

You know I was a kid, somehow those clothes and food

just magically appears in the house.

So it was all about skipping school

and in this case playing in front of a live audience.

It was a lot of fun to play, at least Silver Spoons

for an established character named Derek.

I'm sorry, it's just this darn puberty.

(audience laughing)

[TV Announcer] Sunday on Knight Rider,

a shocking accident destroys kid's memory.

Stay away from me.

[TV Announcer] Can guest star Jason Bateman

help Michael save him?

There was an episode of Knight Rider I remember

where I was 15 so I couldn't yet legally drive

but I got to drive the Kit car, the Knight Rider car,

I remember that was even more excited than skipping school.

I got to drive this Trans Am.

And of course, David Hasselhoff being there

was pretty sweet too.

Skip school and drive a car and chum it up with The Hoff.

What's this?

(beeping)

And I know we've all given up a lot.

Brian here lost a girlfriend

and well Gurney had to give up the track team

and well, me, I've lost a lot of sleep

between dating Brian's old girlfriend

and the track team practices.

(audience laughing)

After Silver Spoons there was a show called It's Your Move

where I got to play an even more devilish character,

a sort of a conniving con man,

but in school.

Now in junior high we made pocket money

selling hall passes, doctors notes

and even the pimple cream we made out of Crisco and sand.

(audience laughing)

That was a lot of fun.

That only lasted about a year

because NBC was getting notes

from parents across the country

that their kids were starting to do the same things

that they were writing my character to do,

build schemes on how to teach kids how to cheat in school

and steal your neighbor's stuff

and how to make a copy of a key that says Do Not Copy.

So they had to shut it down.

Now we need that $500 to pay the band.

All my money's tied up in municipal bonds.

♪ Hand in hand we face our fears ♪

♪ Together through the years ♪

After It's Your Move was a show called,

well it started out being called Valerie

and then it was called Valerie's Family

and then they switched it to The Hogans

and then The Hogan Family.

So in five and half years there were four titles,

it was one of my favorite jobs of my career, my life

and I love all those people.

That was a really, felt like a really safe cave we were in.

Like we all had a job and it was gonna last forever

and then you realize things go away.

The Hogan Family, that was my first chance to direct.

It's a multi-camera show where there's studio audience

you shoot it like a play.

And it was a lot of fun and very challenging to work out

sort of the puzzle of making sure each camera's

pointed at the next actor who's about to speak,

it was a lot of fun to sort of not drop the ball

for all these adults that were working there

and giving this kid this responsibility.

So that was important that I had this positive

initial experience with directing

and led to my passion, it's such a crappy word,

but that's why I love directing today

because I didn't have a bad experience then.

(howling)

[TV Announcer] Jason Bateman is Teen Wolf Too.

He's going through a few changes.

I don't howl.

You don't see any fangs do ya?

I did my first film when I was 18, I think I was,

it was Teen Wolf Too.

Winner of three separate Academy Awards,

Best Picture, Best Actor and I think we got Director too.

Although I might be confused,

but definitely Actor and Picture.

That was a great decision obviously.

And boy, we just had fun on that.

It didn't feel like we were doing something

Academy Award winning but boy were we wrong.

Check it out, you'll see what we made.

We've arrived.

(howling)

[TV Announcer] Toby Kellogg's been away from his family.

While I was gone, they moved.

Back in those days, there was a movie every week

that the networks would make called The Movie of the Week.

There was one called Moving Target

that I remember had a lot of action, running around,

I remember jumping off a bridge,

this bridge in Century City,

so still to this day every time I drive under it,

I remember shooting that day, that was kinda cool.

Another one where I played my sister's brother.

Ties Justine Bateman

and Jason Bateman in an unforgettable performance.

I have been outside looking into the real world

for so long.

[TV Announcer] Can you feel me dancing, Monday.

She played a blind woman in that.

What do I have to do to get some attention around here?

Go blind?

She was great at that except for one day,

she put her hand through a plate glass window

and cut a nerve.

I think she still does not have feeling

in one of her pinkies to this day.

Watch it, don't take the blind roles.

Where's my family?

[TV Announcer] Jason Bateman is a Moving Target,

Monday after Alf.

I want you to meet my brother Simon.

Alright.

Fireworks.

Maybe he's on to something.

There was a sitcom called Simon

that was right at the beginning of the WB

when that was first coming out.

And we were so low rated

that we were 109th out of 111 shows

maybe that were on TV at the time.

We had hats made for everybody as a Christmas gift

that just said 109 on it.

♪ Well come on ♪

♪ Come on ♪

♪ Baby don't you want to go ♪

Chicago Sons was show that I did

where I played one of three brothers that live in Chicago.

And I remember Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls

and Gabby Reece, they were both guest stars on that.

I thought that was awesome, I'm a big sports fan.

David Krumholtz and D.W. Moffett, we were all brothers

and love those guys.

We had a really good time.

Why don't you and I go in the kitchen and...

And what?

And be in the kitchen.

(audience laughing)

George and Leo was another show that I did.

I played the son of Bob Newhart

which was an incredible honor and thrill.

I remember being able to see Bob Newhart

do a five minute set of stand up comedy

just for that studio audience every Friday

when we would shoot the show.

That was pretty cool.

What do you say?

Whoa, whoa, whoa, slow it down.

When it comes to letting people into my apartment

I have very strict requirements.

I got first and last months rent.

And you've met them all, Vern, refreshments.

Some of My Best Friends was a show

that was a sitcom on CBS which was about a gay man

living with a straight man as roommates

and the hysterics that would come from something like that.

Nowadays, diversity is much much better represented

on television.

I don't think people would think

that was such a mind blowing concept,

but at the time, I guess it was

and we definitely had some fun.

It wasn't a long lasting show though

for one reason or another.

What about wrestling?

I really like to watch wrestling.

So do I.

(audience laughing)

Tell me truth, okay,

'cause there's been a lot of lying in this family.

And a lot of love.

More lies.

Arrested Development was a show

that was clearly a huge huge help to me and my career,

that was a big life preserver for me.

That was an audition that came my way,

an ex-agent, an old agent of mine, called and said,

hey, I'm looking at the breakdown

on this casting for this show

and I see you haven't read for this show,

you should ask your new agents.

So I asked my new agents to send me in on that.

And they said, yeah, you're not gonna want to read for that.

That shows never gonna get on the air.

It's sort of, it's like a mocumentary

add there's a narrator,

Ron Howard's gonna do the narrating

and I don't even know if they're ever

gonna be able to get him.

And apparently there's no dressing rooms,

there's no lights, there's no makeup, it's a mess.

I said, well, can I read it?

They said, sure you can read it if you want.

So I read the script.

Of course it was incredibly funny to read

and I went in and read for it.

And ended up just sort of guessing right

to what they might want out of that role of Michael Bluth.

The guy, the boss, Mitch Hurwitz,

followed me out of the room and said,

hey, you're auditioning tomorrow for this other show

that I'm producing, but this one, you like this.

I said yeah, I'd love to do this show.

He said, great, don't come in for that show tomorrow.

'Cause I don't want that network to see you.

I want you to do this one.

And I was like, did this guy just give me the job?

That was a very exciting day for me and my career.

And of course the show turned out

to be one of my favorite things ever

and I owe a lot to Mitch Hurwitz.

Now, do you want to steer?

Or are you too old to sit on your pop's lap and drive?

I think I might be.

Okay.

Hi, Mark Loring, I'm the husband.

And this of course is Juno.

Like the city in Alaska?

No.

Juno was a film that was really helpful to my film career

because a lot of people loved that movie

and it kind of took off a bit

and it was nominated for Best Picture I believe.

Jason Reitman was a very nice man to put me in that film.

And it was a really fun, positive, high-quality experience.

I work mostly from home, I'm a composer.

Like Johannes Brahms or?

More commercial stuff.

Like what?

Commercials.

If I don't get before eight, she puts on the sweatpants

and once the sweatpants are on, I get nothing.

Hi.

Hon.

Extract was a film that I did.

A Mike Judge film that I just thought

was just a really really funny script, a really funny movie.

Mike Judge is one of the nicest people

you could ever hope to work with.

Kristen Wiig was in it, Mila Kunis, Ben Affleck.

I highly recommend it.

That one sort of was under the radar a bit.

I get paranoid when I smoke pot.

If you smoke a little.

(laughing and coughing)

♪ So when your hopes on fire ♪

I've even done a music video for Mumford and Sons.

Jason Sudeikis called me or emailed me or something

and he said, hey, me and Ed Helms and Will Forte

are gonna get together and play the band Mumford and Sons.

That's kind of all I really needed to hear.

It just sounded ridiculous and we got to play

banjos and be real jackasses

and that was put together beautifully well.

The spelling bee is meant for kids.

Rule number 24, the speller have not have passed

beyond the eighth grade on or before February 1st,

as you can see there,

I have not passed the eighth grade, not ever.

I've always wanted to direct a movie.

I wanted to be father, a husband and direct a movie.

Those are the three things I wanted to do

before I got hit by a bus.

The film was Bad Words.

I'm really happy with it, proud of it,

few people have seen it, they seem to like it.

Although the people that didn't like it,

they're not stopping me on the street

and telling me I suck and that that was garbage

so, I'm in a little bit of a bubble.

A lot of people might hate that movie,

I just don't know about it.

But, I'm hearing from those that did.

There's at least a dozen.

Maybe a bakers.

Hey moms, let's break out the rubber pillowcases tonight,

little pricks are gonna be counting tears not sheep.

Who's next?

And I want to put all $7,945,400 into a hot tub,

get buck naked and play Scrooge McDuck,

that is 100% my business.

Now where's my money?

The directing and the acting

got progressively more comfortable for me

going into Ozark, which to me,

I was excited about the challenge of directing

like a 600 page movie.

I wanted to give it a try and for better or worse,

I couldn't work enough time to prep all the episodes

and ended up just directing four of the 10,

the first two and the last two.

But that's just something I'm really really proud of

because there's just so many people that I managed

to find, talk into coming to work on that show,

cast and crew and Netflix giving us

such a nice generous push and support with it all.

And letting us create kinda this tone and atmosphere

and moodiness and dangerousness and chilling elements

that are all there in the script.

And then trying to figure out what that looks like

and what it sounds like was my job as director and EP

where you make all these choices

to kind of build this environment.

And it's been really really rewarding.

I feel very very fortunate.

Sir, there's no business opportunities

that require that much cash.

Not legal ones.

Well, I agree to disagree.

Staying employed is tough,

success or relevance is paper thin.

And you've got to try to align yourself

with as many talented and kind people as you can

because you need them.

This is not an individual game,

it takes a team and so working with quality people

on quality things is what I think fuels longevity.

And if you want to stay in it for awhile,

look for the good people.
